statement:
Let $S = \{ S_1,S_2,\dots S_n \}$ be a finite collection of finite sets.
There exists a system of distinct representatives of $S$ if and only if
the following condition holds for any $T \subseteq S$:
$$\left | \cup T \right | \geq |T|$$

As a corollary, if this condition fails to hold anywhere, then no SDR
exists.

This is known as Hall’s marriage theorem. The name arises from a
particular application of this theorem. Suppose we have a finite set of
single men/women, and, for each man/woman, a finite collection of
women/men to whom this person is attracted. An SDR for this collection
would be a way each man/woman could be (theoretically) married happily.
Hence, Hall’s marriage theorem can be used to determine if this is
possible.

An application of this theorem to graph theory gives that if
$G(V_1, V_2, E)$ is a bipartite graph, then $G$ has a complete matching
that saturates every vertex of $V_1$ if and only if $|S|\leq |N(S)|$ for
every subset $S\subset V_1$.
